intro: Dimerocostus strobilaceus subsp. strobilaceus, commonly known as the Mexican sunflower, is a herbaceous plant native to Central America and parts of the southern United States. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is characterized by its vibrant orange to yellow ray florets and dark brown disk florets. The plant typically grows to a height of 1–3 meters, with opposite, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. It thrives in full sun and well-drained soil, making it a popular choice for gardeners seeking a bold, colorful ornamental plant. Its flowering period extends from summer to early autumn, adding a striking visual element to landscapes.
